article.title: Riemannian-geometry-based modeling and clustering of network-wide non-stationary time series: The brain-network case

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different colors in the functional connectivity matrices (Figs. 1b-1e) represent?
choices: Different levels of connectivity strength
Different brain regions
Different network states/structures
Different time points

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of features are shown in Figs. 1g-1j?
choices: Partial-correlation matrices
Covariance matrices
BOLD time series
Observability matrices

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is sample averaging necessary for the features in Figs. 1g-1n?
choices: To reduce noise and reveal underlying patterns
To align time series from different subjects
To normalize the feature values
To reduce the dimensionality of the feature space

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the advantage of using partial-correlation matrices without sample averaging (Figs. 1o-1r)?
choices: They require less computational resources.
They capture non-linear dependencies more effectively.
They can be used to characterize dynamically evolving network states.
They are more robust to noise.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the sliding window achieve in the feature-extraction scheme?
choices: It smooths out the time series.
It captures the temporal evolution of network states.
It reduces the dimensionality of the feature space.
It aligns time series from different subjects.
Riemannian multi-manifold modeling
Random manifold matrix model
Resting-state multi-modal measurement
Recursive manifold mapping method

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key difference between RMMM and traditional clustering approaches like Kmeans?
choices: RMMM assumes clusters are submanifolds, while Kmeans assumes they are data clouds.
RMMM uses Riemannian geometry, while Kmeans uses Euclidean geometry.
RMMM allows for intersecting clusters, while Kmeans does not.
All of the above.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the tubular neighborhoods represent in Fig. 3a?
choices: Areas where data points are more likely to belong to a specific cluster.
Areas where noise and mis-modeling errors are more prevalent.
Areas where the manifold curvature is high.
Areas where the geodesic distance is minimized.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the logarithm map in Fig. 3b?
choices: To project data points onto the tangent space.
To compute the geodesic distance between data points.
To estimate the dimensionality of the submanifold.
To cluster data points based on their angular information.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the role of local PCA in GCT?
choices: To reduce the dimensionality of the feature space.
To estimate the tangent space of the submanifold.
To compute the sparse coding weights.
To identify the cluster centers.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of information is captured by the empirical geodesic angles in GCT?
choices: The distance between data points.
The similarity between data points.
The orientation of the submanifold at a specific point.
The curvature of the manifold.
The kernel function
The kernel-based partial correlation (kPC)
The generalized Schur complement
The observability matrix

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the inverse kernel matrix (K^-1) in this formula?
choices: It accounts for non-linear dependencies between nodes.
It removes the influence of other nodes on the pair being considered.
It normalizes the kernel function.
It projects data points onto the tangent space.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the advantage of using kernel-based PCs over traditional linear PCs?
choices: They are more robust to noise.
They are computationally less expensive.
They can capture non-linear dependencies between nodes.
They are easier to interpret.
